metadata.title: Plotly Dash vs Streamlit — Which is the best library for building data dashboard web apps? | by JP Hwang | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Plotly Dash vs Streamlit — Which is the best library for building data dashboard web apps?
metadata.description: But we all know that practicalities are not sayings, and in most cases, finding the right tool is no trivial task. This holds true even for a relative niche field of data visualisation for Python…

all_paragraphs: They say that there’s always a right tool for the job.
But we all know that practicalities are not sayings, and in most cases, finding the right tool is no trivial task.

This holds true even for a relative niche field of data visualisation for Python. There exists a ton of amazing tools like Plotly, Altair, Bokeh and the classics such as matplotlib, seaborn and ggplot. That’s not even counting those in other languages, like D3.js, ggplot2 or Highcharts.
Finding them, and then going on to do research on each package to compare their pros and cons can be exhausting.
In addition, if you want to share your outputs as web apps or add interactivity, the search and research criteria become more complex, adding further difficulty to the search and research.

So in this post, I compare a couple of leading data dashboarding packages — namely, Plotly’s Dash, which is arguably the industry leader in this space, and a newer entrant to the scene called Streamlit.
In the spirit of data visualisation, the next chart tells the story so far.

Dash hasn’t been around that long in context of normal time. But in the context of data science and open-source software, 3 years is a lifetime. And in that time, it’s racked up over 12k stars on GitHub.

Meanwhile, Streamlit has been around barely a year, during which time its popularity has risen rapidly. It’s not yet quite as popular as Dash by this metric, nor does it quite have Dash’s community, but Streamlit has got pretty impressive momentum behind it.
In other words, they are both tremendously popular libraries, and for good reasons as you will see.
Streamlit’s focus is towards rapid prototyping, whereas Dash focusses on production / enterprise settings.
At this point, it is worth pointing out two key differences in philosophy between the two libraries, from which some of the design decisions are derived.

One, Streamlit appears to be more aimed towards rapidly prototyping an app, whereas Dash appears more directed at a production / enterprise environment. An observation of their websites (screenshots from late July 2020) really confirm this hypothesis. And as you will see below, this leads to some design decisions and functionality differences.
Second, Dash is primarily designed to work with Plotly , whereas Streamlit is more agnostic to the underlying visualisation libraries such as Altair, Bokeh, Plotly, Seaborn, or Matplotlib.
Note: I erroneously indicated in an earlier version of this article that Dash was only compatible with Plotly — this was incorrect. Examples of using third party libraries can be found here.

What all that means is that I think they are both amazing tools, built for slightly different purposes. As such, and the choice of the right tool might be dependent on your use case, as well as your background.
To follow along, install a few packages — plotly, dash, dash-bootstrap-components and streamlit. Install each (in your virtual environment) with a simple pip install [PACKAGE_NAME].
To evaluate the dashboarding aspect only, we simply load an existing figure from a JSON file, and build our web app around it. This is the script.
If you want to see the code, you can find the accompanying git repo here.
Let’s begin our comparison in earnest. If you are here, you might be relatively new to both (or at least one). So what’s the learning curve like?
Both of them do a great job by making it super simple to spin up a web app.
This is the code needed to generate a fully functioning Dash app:
And this is the code needed to produce the same graph in Streamlit,
With the caveat that the Streamlit script needs to be run externally with a shell command:
Amazingly, both libraries are able to produce a functioning web app in under ten lines of code.
The above was cute, but that’s not quite indicative of a real web app.
An actual web app would do more than serve one figure. Let’s begin to add a few more bits and pieces to this app, to see how the two libraries handle them.
To approximate elements that an actual dashboard might contain, we will add a title, some placeholder text, and an interactive component, which we will use to change colours on the figure.
Here is where the diverging philosophies between Dash and Streamlit begin to show. This is what my code in Dash looks like, having added these elements:
This is the equivalent app, built with Streamlit:

You’ll notice that the Streamlit version of the script is shorter, it flows more linearly (I didn’t need to build additional functions, or callbacks — we’ll come back go this point later), and the functions are not related to the underlying html that is used to render the page.
Dash is slightly more verbose than Streamlit, whereas Streamlit takes care of more decisions for you so that the user can concentrate on building the data science / analysis aspect.
You’ll notice for example that in Streamlit, the command st.write() can be used to add a Plotly figure, or to simply add body text.

To be clear, neither philosophy isn’t inherently better than the other — these are design choices. Having said that, as far as learning curve go, this means that Streamlit is easier to pick up and get going with.
As another point, if you are looking to use a graphics package that is not Plotly, adopting Streamlit means you can continue to use that and not have to learn Plotly.
One outcome of Streamlit’s focus on rapid prototyping means that it is far, far more opinionated than Dash.

At the base level, it might seem that a Streamlit app looks better than a Dash app. Above, I cheated slightly by adding a pre-programmed stylesheet. Here is the same app, but “out-of-the-box” (i.e. no formatting applied) in Dash.
Look at all that default HTML formatting — taking us straight back to 1995!!

But, that is by design (no pun intended). While they provide a default stylesheet for lazy folks like me, Dash is styling-agnostic out of the box, which means you can apply whatever styling you might prefer. In fact, third party libraries like dash-bootstrap-components make it a cinch to apply existing bootstrap stylesheets.
With just a line or two of code here:

We can apply any of these themes from the Bootwatch themes. This means you do not have to reinvent the wheel, and you can take advantage of the amazing work that’s been done by the Bootstrap community. Just by editing that last (bolded) part of the above code, I can change the look of the app drastically.
And in enterprise settings — where you might have to meet company style guides, Dash is the only choice out of these two.
So for me, while Streamlit provides a very good looking styling out of the box, the superior flexibility of Dash and the ability to leverage existing Bootstrap themes gives it the nod.
Aesthetics: Advantage Dash, for flexibility & Bootstrap compatibility
This is another area where the different philosophies of the two projects significant affect the resulting product behaviour.

As you might have seen in my code above, Dash uses the concept of “callbacks” to add in interactivity. Functions need to be set up so that whenever a linked input changes, it triggers the function (like the update_fig() function above).

This might be more verbose, but then the Dash app only needs to re-run the function that has been called. On the other hand, Streamlit is configured so that any time an input is changed, all of the app is re-run.

Now, it does provide a caching functionality to circumvent some of this, but it definitely is a limitation, having to re-run the entire script every time that an input is changed. I’d give Dash the nod here again.
Performance: Advantage Dash for callback-based modularity
What I mean here by “functionality” is basically which library can you do more, or build better apps, with.
Streamlit boasts its compatibility with many of the giants of the machine learning space — take a look at their website:
Now, some of these are obviously marking fluff — all python libraries, like Streamlit, are going to be compatible with… python. And many of these aren’t even graphics libraries.

Still, the fact that you can say, mix and match visualisations built with Altair, Bokeh, and Plotly into one presentation is quite an advantage, because each have strengths and weaknesses, and in a team setting each member might prefer to work with one above another.

This isn’t Dash’s forte. Although third party libraries can be used to some extent (see this proof-of-concept library), it’s built by Plotly primarily for the Plotly.py library. But, where Dash does shine is its healthy library of existing modules built for it.

Thanks to its maturity, community support and enterprise adoption, it has had time to build in a whole host of modules not just for interactivity, or html wrapping, but also for specialised modules for DAQ integration, in the bioinformatics space, and network visualisation.
I’d call this a tie, with each library stronger than another in a key area.
Functionality: Tie, Streamlit for compatibility to viz libraries, Dash for its robust modules library

This one is an easy one to answer, although probably unfair — here’s why. It’s an easy win for Dash; and the reason that it is an unfair contest is that Dash a much, much, more mature product with a big community of users, and its history means there’s been a huge amount of time for people to have asked questions and received answers.

Not only that, there exist a huge library of third party repos, tutorials and articles for Plotly due to its maturity. These all act as supplementary documentation, and is another source of advantage for Plotly.

This isn’t to say that the documentation for Streamlit is bad. It’s very good, and they also have a forum where you could ask questions or share showcases. It’s just not as good as Dash’s documentation, or nearly as big as its forum.
Could Streamlit catch up in a year or two? Possibly. For now, Dash is far superior in this regard.
Where does that all leave us?
I mentioned above that choice of the right tool between these two might be dependent on your use case and the background.

If your goal is to quickly build a good-looking data visualisation app for prototyping and sharing with others, or if you are determined to use something other than Plotly as the underlying visualisation package, Streamlit is the way to go.

Streamlit is the easier to pick up out of the two. It is designed with a stated goal of quick prototyping, and as such it tends to be more succinct. It is also compatible with multiple visualisation packages like Bokeh, Altair or matplotlib.

But, if you are looking to build an enterprise-level app, if performance is of paramount importance, if you are looking to style the app to your liking (e.g. a corporate style guide), Dash is the way to go.
Also, the depth and breadth of available modules, app repos and documentation means that the more complex the app becomes, it might be advantageous to go with Dash.
If you liked this, say 👋 / follow on twitter, or follow here for updates.
Edit: I’m starting a Substack for all things Data and Visualisation — it is going to be a way for me to engage directly with you. I would love for you to join me here.
I also wrote a little about why I’m starting a Substack.
ICYMI: I also wrote this article about building a web data dashboard with Dash.
If you are interested in how I made the basketball visualisation that I use here:
